content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It was trickier and took longer than I originally thought, because  I made a wrong assumption of the mosaic width being divisible by the pattern width But the statement was correctly not claiming this, so my mistake.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Simple and easy to solve puzzle, the examples are well chosen.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice easy puzzle with clear statement and difficulty level well chosen.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

Input section contains error.
Next 12 lines: a string that constitutes a row of the mosaic.
Number of lines = N

This puzzle has great potential for me.
However I think that making a smaller and more readable entry for the first example could help to better understand the problem and to see if the output that we obtain is the one that we can have with a simple glance.

I like this, my first community comment, please forgive me if not useful:

• In the Contraints, maybe add in lines/tiles=12
• This puzzle can be made into another version, which is the mosaic is a dynamic square, with tiles with random range, e.g. 8<=tiles<=20

Hey, thanks for the feedback!

Indeed, I originally created this puzzle for a Clash of Code and thus made the inputs quite simple.

I think having mosaic with different sizes is a good idea, I modified the puzzle in this direction.

I added another input, where the pattern shifting vary from one row to the other.

I also thought about having some tests with a pattern that is wider than the mosaic. It would make the solution a bit more complex but I'm not sure if that's relevant for the easy section.

Thanks for the feedback! 

I added a new first Test/Validator with a simpler, smaller mosaic. I hope it makes the puzzle clearer!
Whoops! Thanks for pointing that out, the error remained from a previous version where the grid size was fixed.
